video-config.troubleshootingIntro: If you're having any trouble getting your webcam set up, please email Anthi Georgiadou <ageor006@gold.ac.uk> with a brief description of the problem.

video-consent.PIName: Anthi Georgiadou, Dr Caspar Addyman and Prof. Lauren Stewart
video-consent.PIContact: Anthi Georgiadou at ageor006@gold.ac.uk, or Dr Caspar Addyman at c.addyman@gold.ac.uk, or Prof Lauren Stewart at l.stewart@gold.ac.uk
video-consent.purpose: While infant engagement to music is well documented, the role familiarity has on it is still underexplored. We are interested to investigate how babies' response to music changes as they become more familiar with a specific song.
video-consent.procedures: We ask that your child is sat in a highchair and that their full body is viewable. Your child will hear to the standard version of the Happy song on days 1 and 7 we will record if and how they move to it. We will then ask you to complete an online survey. There are no anticipated risks associated with participating.
video-consent.datause: We are interested in your child's engagement with the Happy Song. We will use specialist software to measure the timing of your child’s respones. We will look at these data in light of your survey responses.
video-consent.payment: There is no compensation for taking part in this study. We cannot promise any benefits to you or others from your taking part in this research. You will not receive results of the procedures and tasks your child performs as part of this research. Our conclusions are about how groups of children respond, and therefore individual results are not meaningful. However, possible benefits include learning more about research with children.
video-consent.Publication of results: The results of the research may be presented at scientific meetings or published in scientific journals. Raw data (for instance, the number of times your child made a particular movement) may be published when it cannot identify children. We never publish children's birthdates or names, and we never publish your demographic data in conjunction with your child's video.
video-consent.research_rights_statement: This research has been reviewed and approved by the ethics committee at Goldsmiths, University of London. You should also know that you may contact any of the following people if you are unhappy about the way your data or your participation in this study are being treated: 1)  Goldsmiths Data Protection Officer – dp@gold.ac.uk  (concerning your rights to control personal data). 2) Chair, Goldsmiths Research Ethics and Integrity Sub-Committee - via reisc@gold.ac.uk, REISC Secretary (for any other element of the study). 3) You also have the right to lodge a complaint with the Information Commissioner’s Office at https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/
video-consent.gdpr_personal_data: your email address, child's date of birth
video-consent.gdpr_sensitive_data: your racial or ethnic origin, video images of you and your child

blocks.title: What you (parent or guardian) have to do:

listblocks.text: The most important role you have during the study is to make sure your child stays in front of the computer.
You can encourage them to stay engaged but please do not demonstrate any dancing

blocks.title: What to do when the study is finished:

listblocks.text: Once the study has finished playing, you’ll be given an opportunity to report any technical problems you may have experienced along the way.
Then, you be asked to select a privacy level for your videos.
Finally, we will take you to our questionnaire - you can complete this at a later date if preferred .

intro-video.introText:
Welcome to the study! Please watch this video to get started. 
(Or you can read the summary to the right if you prefer.)

listblocks.text: Your baby does not need to be with you at this point in the study. We will let you know when it is time to get your baby.

Hi and thank you for taking part in this study. We’re interested in how infants' response to a specific song changes as they become more familiar with it, and so in this study, we’re asking that your little one is sat in their highchair with their full body, from their head to their toes visible on camera. This might require you to position your device at the same level as the highchair table, or at some distance from your baby so we can be sure to capture their full body movement. They will listen to the standard version of the Happy Song. It’s really important that your baby isn’t influenced by your movement, so please resist any urges to sway or dance in any way! If you feel your infant needs a break, you can pause by pressing the spacebar. Thanks so much and on with the study!

intro-video.warningText: Please watch the video or read the summary before proceeding.

intro-video.title: Study instructions

blocks.title: What to do during the study:

listblocks.text: If your child gets fussy or distracted during the study, or you need to attend to something else for a moment, you can pause the study by pressing the spacebar.
If you notice that your child is becoming bored or too fussy to finish the study, that is perfectly OK and quite common. You are free to discontinue their participation in the study at any point.
If you need to end the study early, you can press ctr-X or the F1 key to end the study. Select “exit” in the box that will appear on the screen. This will take you to the end of the study.
Please make sure we have a good full body view of your little one during the study. The best position for your child would be in a highchair.

Above is an example of what we would like to see. You may have to position your device at the same level as the highchair table, or at some distance from your baby so we can be sure to capture their full body movement and facial expression.
Don’t worry if you feel your child becoming disinterested, we are still collecting valuable data.

webcamBlocks.title: It's time to get your child & check yourself out!

listblocks.text: Take a few moments to get settled and use the webcam preview to make sure your child’s full body is in view. Also be sure that it isn’t too dark, and that you are not blocking the view of your child.
The green button down below will take you to the beginning of the study. So, press the button when you and your child are in position and ready to go.

parentTextBlock.title: If your child needs a break, press the space bar.
parentTextBlock.text: This will pause study and let restart the song when they are ready.

debriefing.title: Thank you for participating in our study!

blocks.title: What was this study about?
blocks.text:
The Happy Song was specially designed to appeal to babies. But we are interested in how children's response to this song before and after a week of listening. During that week different children will hear the song differently (original version, amateur version, parent singing).

 We will measure how your child changed their movements and expression in the two videos. We will then combine this with information you provide in our questionnaire. This will give us new insights infant perception of music.

blocks.title: What happens next?
blocks.text:
Now that your little one has done some brilliant listening for us, it is your turn to take part! The exit button takes you to our survey asking questions about the musical environment of your home. 

 It would be appreciated if you could complete the survey as soon as possible. If you can’t do it all now, you can pause and come back to the survey later. We will shortly send you an email with a link to the survey. We hope you enjoy the final part of the study!
